Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: A sermon must be delivered for a High Holiday service, which the entire congregation is expected to attend.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the technical specs for the core module open on one side, and my notes for the High Holiday sermon on the other. My phone buzzed with a message from my project manager: “We’re all waiting on your module. The build can’t move forward until it’s done.” I could almost feel the weight of my team’s expectations pressing down on me. At the same time, my inbox filled with reminders from the synagogue board—this sermon wasn’t just any message; it was the High Holiday, the one time of year when every seat would be filled, every ear tuned to my words. I knew how much the congregation needed inspiration, especially this year. My mind raced, torn between the urgent technical challenge and the spiritual responsibility. I felt my heart pounding, anxiety rising as I tried to focus, but the demands of both worlds pulled me in opposite directions. I closed my eyes, wrestling with the impossible choice: deliver the code my team needed, or the sermon my community expected.
